Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story: Tonight, my mother called me into the living room, her eyes shining with pride. “It’s your turn to lead the family ceremony this year,” she said, handing me the old, embroidered sash my grandmother once wore. I knew how much this meant to her, to all of us—preserving our traditions, honoring our ancestors. But as I held the sash, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the online candidate forum for our district was starting. I’d promised myself I’d watch, ask questions, and be an informed citizen. The election was close, and my voice mattered. My family expected me to carry on our customs, to be present and respectful. My community expected me to participate, to help shape our future. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing on me, my heart racing as I glanced between my mother’s hopeful face and the glowing screen. I wanted to be the daughter my family needed, but I also wanted to be the citizen my community deserved. The ceremony was about to begin, and the forum was already live. I stood frozen, torn between two worlds, unsure which part of myself to honor first.
